quiz.text: Which of the following is not accounted in the calculation of GDP? 1) Non Market transactions 2) Health of people 3) Economic inequality 4) Depreciation of capital Select the correct answer using the code given below:
options: 1, 2 and 3 only
1, 3 and 4 only
2, 3 and 4 only
1, 2 and 4 only
1, 2, 3 and 4

quiz.text: Which of the following gives an idea about the maximum amount of goods and services the domestic economy has at its disposal?
options: Private Income
Per Capita Income
National Disposable Income
National Income
Personal Disposable Income

quiz.text: Which of the following statements is not correct with reference to households?
options: Households undertake consumption expenditure
They supply labour, capital, land, and entrepreneurial ability
They demand goods and services from product markets
They are involved in the investment expenditure
None of the above

quiz.text: Which of the following statement is not correct?
options: Income, or output, or profits are called flows
Flows are defined over a period of time
The buildings or machines in a factory are classified under stocks
Measurement of a change in the quantity of a machine over a specific period of time is stock
Stocks are defined at a particular point of time

quiz.text: Which of the following methods can be used to measure Gross Domestic Product of an economy? 1) Income Method 2) Expenditure Method 3) Demand Method 4) Production Method Select the correct answer using the code given below:
options: 1, 2, 3 and 4
1, 2 and 3 only
2, 3 and 4 only
1, 3 and 4 only
1, 2 and 4 only

quiz.text: GDP, or Gross Domestic Product, is defined as
options: Value of all intermediate goods and services produced within the country within one year
Value of all consumer goods and services produced for the marketplace over a period of time by the citizens of that country
Total monetary or market value of all the final goods and services produced within a country's borders in a specific time period
The value of all the capital goods produced over a period of time in a country
None of the above

quiz.text: The most appropriate measure of a country's economic growth is its
options: Gross Domestic Product (GDP)
Net Domestic Product (NDP)
Net National Product (NNP)
Per Capita Product
Gross National Product ( GNP)

quiz.text: If saving exceeds investment, the national income will
options: Fall
Fluctuate
Remain constant
Rise
Fall, rise then fall

quiz.text: Which of the following are the receipts of a production house? 1) Cost on imports 2) Borrowings 3) Subsidies 4) Savings Select the correct answer using the code given below:
options: 1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only
1 and 3 only
3 and 4 only
1 and 4 only

quiz.text: Which of the following are the expenditure for a government in an economy? 1) Taxes 2) Transfer payments 3) Grants 4) Scholarships Select the correct answer using the code given below:
options: 1, 2 and 3 only
1, 3 and 4 only
2, 3 and 4 only
1, 2 and 4 only
1, 2, 3 and 4

quiz.text: How can a socialist economy be best described?
options: An economy in which decisions are made by the government rather than by the interaction between consumers and businesses
The international exchange of goods and services
An economy based on supply and demand with little or no government control
An economy that combines characteristics of capitalism and socialism
None of the above

quiz.text:
Consider the following statements:
  1. India’s GNP is always lower than its GDP.
  2. GNP is the ‘national income’ according to which the IMF ranks the nations of the world in terms of the volumes at purchasing power parity (PPP).
  3. In India the National Income is calculated at market cost and constant prices.
Which of the above statements is/are correct?
options: 1 only
1 and 2 only
1, 2 and 3
2 only
3 only

quiz.text: In a closed economy, the Gross Domestic Product (Y) of the economy is: (C, I, G, X, M stand for Consumption, Investment, Govt. Expenditure, total exports and total imports respectively.) Which of the following best represents the GDP?
options: Y = C + I + G + X
Y = I + G –X + M
Y = C + I + G + (X – M)
Y = C – G + I + (X – M)
Y = C + I + G

quiz.text: Which of the following is not one of the factors of production?
options: Water
Supervisors
Vehicles
Machinery
Interest

quiz.text: Economic Growth and Economic Development are two terms which are often used interchangeably to express Economic Progress. However, the truth is that there is an enormous difference, that of quantity and quality. The comprehensive knowledge, pertaining to the difference in meaning of these two terms, aids in the in-depth analyses of the economic journey undertaken by different nations. Economic Development refers to an increase in the volume of goods and services produced and consumed along with improved living circumstances, with equitable distribution, improved healthcare service outcomes, by making education accessible to all, by enhancing the overall quality of personal, social and professional conditions and most importantly without environmental degradation. Economic Growth refers to an increase in size evident through physical change. Economic Development, on the other hand, refers to a process of gradual transformation and improvement in the level of functioning of an economy based on the acquisition of quality abilities. Q. Which model of growth was adopted by India post-independence?
options: Capitalist Model
Socialist Model
Mixed Model
Harrod- Domer Model
None of the above

quiz.text: Economic Growth and Economic Development are two terms which are often used interchangeably to express Economic Progress. However, the truth is that there is an enormous difference; that of quantity and quality. The comprehensive knowledge, pertaining to the difference in meaning of these two terms, aids in the in-depth analyses of the economic journey undertaken by different nations. Economic Growth refers to an increase in size evident through physical change. Economic Development, on the other hand, refers to a process of gradual transformation and improvement in the level of functioning of an economy based on the acquisition of quality abilities. Q. Which of the following ministries is responsible for the report on India’s national and per capita income?
options: Ministry of Home- Affairs
Ministry of Planning
Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation
Ministry of Education
Ministry of Finance

quiz.text: Economic Growth and Economic Development are two terms which are often used interchangeably to express Economic Progress. However, the truth is that there is an enormous difference; that of quantity and quality. The comprehensive knowledge, pertaining to the difference in meaning of these two terms, aids in the in-depth analyses of the economic journey undertaken by different nations. Economic Development refers to an increase in the volume of goods and services produced and consumed along with improved living circumstances, with equitable distribution, improved healthcare service outcomes, by making education accessible to all, by enhancing the overall quality of personal, social and professional conditions and most importantly without environmental degradation. Economic Growth refers to an increase in size evident through physical change. Economic Development, on the other hand, refers to a process of gradual transformation and improvement in the level of functioning of an economy based on the acquisition of quality abilities. Q. As economic development proceeds, income inequality tends to follow a(n) __________ curve
options: Convex
Inverted U shaped
L shaped
S shaped
W shaped

quiz.text: Economic Growth and Economic Development are two terms which are often used interchangeably to express Economic Progress. However, the truth is that there is an enormous difference; that of quantity and quality. The comprehensive knowledge, pertaining to the difference in meaning of these two terms, aids in the in-depth analyses of the economic journey undertaken by different nations. Economic Development refers to an increase in the volume of goods and services produced and consumed along with improved living circumstances, with equitable distribution, improved healthcare service outcomes, by making education accessible to all, by enhancing the overall quality of personal, social and professional conditions and most importantly without environmental degradation. Economic Growth refers to an increase in size evident through physical change. Economic Development, on the other hand, refers to a process of gradual transformation and improvement in the level of functioning of an economy based on the acquisition of quality abilities. Q. Which of the following is not correct?
options: Development is a quantitative process
Education is a  goal oriented process
Learning is a process of behavioural Change
Growth is a biological Process
Both A and D

quiz.text: Thirty years ago, UNDP created a new way to conceive and measure progress. Instead of using growth in GDP as the sole measure of development, we ranked the world’s countries by their human development: by whether people in each country have the freedom and opportunity to live the lives they value. The 2020 Human Development Report (HDR) doubles down on the belief that people’s agency and empowerment can bring about the action we need if we are to live in balance with the planet in a fairer world. It shows that we are at an unprecedented moment in history, in which human activity has become a dominant force shaping the planet. These impacts interact with existing inequalities, threatening significant development reversals. Nothing short of a great transformation – in how we live, work and cooperate – is needed to change the path we are on. The Report explores how to jumpstart that transformation. Q. How many dimensions are covered under the Multidimensionally poverty index?
options: Three
Four
Five
Six
Ten

quiz.text:
Thirty years ago, UNDP created a new way to conceive and measure progress. Instead of using growth in GDP as the sole measure of development, we ranked the world’s countries by their human development: by whether people in each country have the freedom and opportunity to live the lives they value.

The 2020 Human Development Report (HDR) doubles down on the belief that people’s agency and empowerment can bring about the action we need if we are to live in balance with the planet in a fairer world. It shows that we are at an unprecedented moment in history, in which human activity has become a dominant force shaping the planet. These impacts interact with existing inequalities, threatening significant development reversals. Nothing short of a great transformation – in how we live, work and cooperate – is needed to change the path we are on. The Report explores how to jumpstart that transformation.

Q. What is the theme of the recent United Nations Development Report 2020?
options: People's Participation
Globalization with a human face
Gender and Human Development
Human development and Anthropocene
Beyond income, beyond averages and beyond today.

quiz.text:
Thirty years ago, UNDP created a new way to conceive and measure progress. Instead of using growth in GDP as the sole measure of development, we ranked the world’s countries by their human development: by whether people in each country have the freedom and opportunity to live the lives they value.

The 2020 Human Development Report (HDR) doubles down on the belief that people’s agency and empowerment can bring about the action we need if we are to live in balance with the planet in a fairer world. It shows that we are at an unprecedented moment in history, in which human activity has become a dominant force shaping the planet. These impacts interact with existing inequalities, threatening significant development reversals. Nothing short of a great transformation – in how we live, work and cooperate – is needed to change the path we are on. The Report explores how to jumpstart that transformation.

Q. Which of the following is not the Indicator in the standard of living Dimension of the Multidimensionally poverty Index?
options: Electricity
Drinking water
Cooking fuel
Sanitation
Nutrition

quiz.text:
Thirty years ago, UNDP created a new way to conceive and measure progress. Instead of using growth in GDP as the sole measure of development, we ranked the world’s countries by their human development: by whether people in each country have the freedom and opportunity to live the lives they value.

The 2020 Human Development Report (HDR) doubles down on the belief that people’s agency and empowerment can bring about the action we need if we are to live in balance with the planet in a fairer world. It shows that we are at an unprecedented moment in history, in which human activity has become a dominant force shaping the planet. These impacts interact with existing inequalities, threatening significant development reversals. Nothing short of a great transformation – in how we live, work and cooperate – is needed to change the path we are on. The Report explores how to jumpstart that transformation.

Q. What is India's ranking in the recent human development report released by UNDP in 2020 ?
options: 131
145
89
101
72

quiz.text: India is the world’s sixth largest economy and is slated to grow at a fast clip in the coming decade with an ambitious target of becoming a $5-trillion economy by 2025. It has now become one of the major growth engines of the world economy. Since the beginning of this century, India’s per capita GDP has grown almost 6.5 times. During this period, the growth in India’s per capita GDP was also one of the fastest among the large emerging markets. The consumption story in India has multiple drivers. Firstly, there is emerging evidence of a revival in income growth. Rising income and expansion of the middle-income segment is likely to fuel future consumption growth. Secondly, India has a highly diverse population which has multiple requirements and needs. Further, with the rural-urban gap diminishing, consumption could get a further boost. Endorsing this is the fact that urbanisation is increasing at a strong pace and India’s urbanisation rate is expected to improve to 40% by 2030. And finally, technology advancements are connecting people and businesses in multiple ways and enabling better information discovery and seamless transactions. Q. Which among the following is not the method adopted across the globe to measure the GDP ?
options: Value added Method / Product Method
Expenditure Method
Income Method
Cross- Border Method
None of the above

quiz.text:
India is the world’s sixth largest economy and is slated to grow at a fast clip in the coming decade with an ambitious target of becoming a $5-trillion economy by 2025. It has now become one of the major growth engines of the world economy. Since the beginning of this century, India’s per capita GDP has grown almost 6.5 times. During this period, the growth in India’s per capita GDP was also one of the fastest among the large emerging markets. The consumption story in India has multiple drivers. Firstly, there is emerging evidence of a revival in income growth. Rising income and expansion of the middle-income segment is likely to fuel future consumption growth. Secondly, India has a highly diverse population that has multiple requirements and needs. Further, with the rural-urban gap diminishing, consumption could get a further boost. Endorsing this is the fact that urbanisation is increasing at a strong pace and India’s urbanisation rate is expected to improve to 40% by 2030. And finally, technology advancements are connecting people and businesses in multiple ways and enabling better information discovery and seamless transactions. Q. Which of the following are the sub-sectors under Industry? 
  1. Mining and quarrying 
  2. Construction 
  3. Real Estate 
  4. Transport 
  5. Communication 
Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
options: 2 and 3 only
1, 2 and 4 only
3, 4 and 5 only
1 and 2 Only
3 and 4 only

quiz.text: India is the world’s sixth largest economy and is slated to grow at a fast clip in the coming decade with an ambitious target of becoming a $5-trillion economy by 2025. It has now become one of the major growth engines of the world economy. Since the beginning of this century, India’s per capita GDP has grown almost 6.5 times. During this period, the growth in India’s per capita GDP was also one of the fastest among the large emerging markets. The consumption story in India has multiple drivers. Firstly, there is emerging evidence of a revival in income growth. Rising income and expansion of the middle-income segment is likely to fuel future consumption growth. Secondly, India has a highly diverse population which has multiple requirements and needs. Further, with the rural-urban gap diminishing, consumption could get a further boost. Endorsing this is the fact that urbanisation is increasing at a strong pace and India’s urbanisation rate is expected to improve to 40% by 2030. And finally, technology advancements are connecting people and businesses in multiple ways and enabling better information discovery and seamless transactions. Q. What is the formula of GDP according to the Value-added Method?
options: GVA = GDP + Subsidies on products - taxes on Products
GDP =  GDP  - Subsidies on products + taxes on Products
GDP = Consumption expenditure + Investment Expenditure + Government Expenditure + Net Imports
GDP = Consumption expenditure - Investment Expenditure + Government Expenditure + Net Imports
GDP = Consumption + Savings + Taxes

quiz.text: India is the world’s sixth largest economy and is slated to grow at a fast clip in the coming decade with an ambitious target of becoming a $5-trillion economy by 2025. It has now become one of the major growth engines of the world economy. Since the beginning of this century, India’s per capita GDP has grown almost 6.5 times. During this period, the growth in India’s per capita GDP was also one of the fastest among the large emerging markets. The consumption story in India has multiple drivers. Firstly, there is emerging evidence of a revival in income growth. Rising income and expansion of the middle-income segment is likely to fuel future consumption growth. Secondly, India has a highly diverse population that has multiple requirements and needs. Further, with the rural-urban gap diminishing, consumption could get a further boost. Endorsing this is the fact that urbanisation is increasing at a strong pace and India’s urbanisation rate is expected to improve to 40% by 2030. And finally, technology advancements are connecting people and businesses in multiple ways and enabling better information discovery and seamless transactions. Q. Which of the following statements is correct?
options: GDP at factor cost = NDP at factor cost + Depreciation
GDP at factor cost = NDP at factor cost - Depreciation
GDP at factor cost = NDP at factor cost + indirect tax
GDP at factor cost = NDP at factor cost + direct tax
None of the above

quiz.text:
Which of the following measures will spur economic growth?
  1. Transparent and hassle-free land acquisition.
  2. Availability of Skilled labour.
  3. High-interest rates in the economy.
  4. The decrease in effective demand.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
options: 1 and 2  only
2, 3 and 4 only
1, 3 and 4 only
1, 2, 3 and 4
1, 2 and 4 only

quiz.text: Consider the following statements 1. Net National Product at factor cost is “National Income” 2. National Disposable Income = Net National product at market prices + other current transfers from the rest of the world Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
options: Only 1
Only 2
Both 1 and 2
Neither 1 nor 2
Any of the above

quiz.text:
Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct about GDP Deflator?
  1. The GDP Deflator measures the ratio of nominal to real GDP.
  2. GDP Deflator measures the change in the price level between the base year and the current year.
  3. GDP deflator does not include prices of imported goods.
The correct answer code is:
options: Only 1 and 2
Only 2 and 3
1, 2 and 3
Only 2
Only 1 and 3

quiz.text: Consider the following statements and identify which of the following are true. ?1. While calculating GDP, income generated by foreigners in a country is taken into consideration 2. While calculating GDP, income generated by nationals of a country outside the country is taken into account 3. While calculating GNP, income generated by foreigners in a country is taken into consideration 4. While calculating GNP, income generated by nationals of a country outside the country is taken into account
options: Both 1 and 2
Both 3 and 4
Both 1 and 4
Both 2 and 3
All of the above

quiz.text: To know whether the rich are getting richer and the poor getting poorer. it is necessary to compare
options: The availability of food grains among two sets of people, one rich and the other poor. over different periods of time
The distribution of income of an identical set of income recipients in different periods of time
The wholesale price index over different periods of time for different regions
The distribution of income of different sets of income recipients at a point of time
All of the above

quiz.text: A decrease in tax to GDP ratio of a country indicates which of the following? 1. Slowing economic growth rate 2. Less equitable distribution of national income  3. Less number of tax evaders Select the correct answer using the code given below.
options: Only 1
Only 2
Only 1 and 3
Only 2 and 3
None of the above

quiz.text: In the context of Indian economy, consider the following statements 1.The growth rate of GDP has steadily increased in the last five years. 2.The growth rate in per capita income has steadily increased in the last five years 3. Inflation during 2021-22 is highest since independence Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
options: Only 1
Only 2
Only 2 and 3
Only 1 and 2
None of the above

quiz.text: Which of the following statements is/are incorrect? 1) GNP is defined as the value of output minus the value of intermediate consumption and is a measure of the contribution to GDP made by an individual producer, industry, or sector. 2) GDP is the monetary value of all finished goods and services produced within a country during a period of one year.  3) GVA is the monetary value of all finished goods and services produced by a country's residents during a period of one year.
options: Only 1
Only 1 and 2
Only 1 and 3
Only 2
2 and 3

quiz.text: The implicit GDP deflator is an index of price change of goods and services, it is measured on the basis of which  of the following criteria.
options: Dividing Nominal GDP by Real GDP and multiplying by 100.
Dividing CPI (Consumer Price index) by rate of Inflation and multiplying by 100.
Dividing Real GDP by Nominal GDP and multiplying by 100.
Dividing Rate of Inflation by CPI (Consumer Price index) and multiplying by 100.
Nominal GDP - Real GDP
